the SNP and Greens obtain independence, they will be able to increase my pension from their abundant resources.Then again, all the SNP’s money trees have been blown down in the recent gales.Perhaps I should rely upon the Scottish Government being in a position to capture one of the flying pigs overhead to fund my state pension when independence is achieved.Yeah, that’s right!

title: the singing kettle returns with arties revival
story: Artie’s Singing Kettle live is on tour and is coming to the Arran High School theatre onAnd Artie’s is back with the original singing kettles packed with favourite songs including: Music Man, Buy me a Banana, Bunny Fou Fou, Eelly Alley O, as well as stories and even some magic tricks.Speaking to the Banner Artie Trezise said it would be the first time he had performed on Arran since staging a school show on the island more than  years ago.He also has fond memories as a child coming to Arran from Cupar in Fe and it was here that he learned to ride a bike.He said: #The show is nostalgia for adults and fun for kids. Bring granny too. We promise not to #Shove Granny off the Bus#.#The Singing Kettle was formed in the early s by Artie and his we Cilla Fisher. Very soon they were joined by Gary Coupland and the three stalwarts were the backbone of the company for more than  years.From the very start Singing Kettle shows have been based on clues for songs inside brightly coloured kettles with the famous chant: #Spout, handle, lid of metal. What#s inside the singing kettle # # which Artie still uses today.While this principle was always central to the action, plot lines and stage sets were built around imaginative story lines, transforming the original concept into a spectacular musical for the whole family.The Singing Kettle turned children’s theatre into an art form and the troupe#s unique performances became the bench mark for fellow professionals everywhere.They performed in hundreds of venues, from the Palladium in London to the Town Hall in Campbeltown, from the Palace Theatre in Kilmarnock to the Royal Palace in Jordan.BAFTA-award winning and decorated with MBEs for services to children’s entertainment, audiences worldwide were hooked on their madcap musical adventures flavoured with cheeky Scottish humour.Adults and children alike found themselves singing the songs together long after the performances were over.The company closed in , with the final line-up forming Fun Box and with Cilla retiring.Artie continued performing solo shows as Artie#s Tartan Tales but since the beginning of  his show is now Artie#s Singing Kettle.There is a £ one price ticket for the show, plus booking fee. Babes in armsare free. Doors open at .pm and the hour long show starts at pm.

title: thought for the week february 25 2022
story: I remember her mixing the batter and dropping the spoonfuls into the pan, four at a time.Then we’d watch for the bubbles and flip them over before transferring them onto a clean dish towel and covering them to keep them warm.Once they were all made, she would make a pot of tea and we would sit with our mugs of tea and fresh pancakes with butter and jam.This memory came to me as I was thinking about this column and what I might write.Lent begins for Christians this coming week, on Ash Wednesday, but many people, religious or not, will celebrate Pancake Tuesday.It’s a great excuse to bake with children and grandchildren. Baking with my gran was a highlight of my childhood.Lent wasn’t really observed by my family or church tradition when I was young, however, later, it became more popular and many people in my tradition now observe the six weeks of Lent.For many people, it’s a chance to give up sweets or chocolate – I never managed that one!In recent years, I have given up giving something up and instead take on something.Often I read a book specic to Lent or I try to do an act of random kindness each day of Lent.I wonder what memories you have of Pancake Tuesday or Lent Jesus, who becomes our focus during Lent, loved to gather with people and share food with them.There isn’t much beats gathering together over food maybe this year you’ll organise a pancake party!Mmh, where did I put that flour

title: district news march 4 2022
story: An exciting extravaganza of automatons was the subject of a display and demonstration at the February meeting of Bellochantuy Scottish Women#s Institute .Andrew Hemmings explained to the ladies that an automaton is basically a mechanical device operating under its own hidden power.Today#s generation may recognise the relationship with robots which are programmed to perform certain tasks but, as the Bellochantuy group learned, these early examples do not rely on modern day technology but with the finely balanced unseen power of yesteryear.#Andrew has an amazing collection of many types of automatons, all of which he has built himself,# said a group spokesperson.#And despite today#s sophisticated examples, the sheer pleasure of seeing these characters in operation, together with Andrew#s description of how they work, was obvious from the fun that we all had watching their antics.#After the presentation, a vote of thanks was given by Jill Lines and this was followed by SWI business.There will be no meeting in March as all West Kintyre SWI groups are holding a combined bulb show, which will include crafts, baking, literature, photography and design.This joint show is being hosted by Whitehouse SWI and the ladies of Bellochantuy are looking forward to meeting friends from the other groups.Tarbert:Tarbert Academy S pupil Yunique Ogunshe is a COP Local Champion.She has been working with a  of young volunteers from Argyll and Bute to take forward the legacy of COP, supported by Ann Kennovin and Jamie Titterton from the Argyll and Bute Community Learning Department Youth Work Team and local climate change action group Time For Change.Yunique is aware of all the fantastic work already going on in Tarbert Academy and the wider community in terms of recycling, local food projects and environmental awareness raising.She has, however, devised a plan through which she hopes to engage even more young people in taking forward the ambitious targets set at the COP conference held last year in Glasgow.As part of this, she invited iniduals and families in Tarbert to create art from items they would otherwise throw away and to take the artwork, or photographs of it, to Tarbert Library for display during February.To kick-start this, she organised an event for secondary pupils at Tarbert Academy after school on Thursday February .The group chatted as they created and were shown the work of Andy Goldsworthy, whose ephemeral and minimalist pieces inspired them to see beauty and potential in objects that would normally be thrown away.Islay:After two Covid-hit years and #virtual only# events, Fèis Ìle – the Islay Festival – is back for .The festival, held at the end of May, draws whisky and Islay fans from across the globe for a -day celebration of Islay, her culture and her spirit.There is music, song, dancing, chatting, meeting friends – old and new – and perhaps a wee dram along the way.The first batch of event tickets sold out in record time, but there are some still available.The Islay distilleries will be announcing their events and programmes over the next couple of months, so look out for those.The Fèis Ìle Facebook page has all the latest updates.

title: dunoon head teacher to take on interim role at grammar
story: In a letter to parents and carers, Argyll and Bute Council#s chief education officer said David Mitchell will take over leadership of Campbeltown Grammar School when Miss Stewart leaves on April , #taking the school forward in the next phase of its development#.The letter reads: #Over the last six months, the local authority has been working hard to recruit a high-quality head teacher for Campbeltown Grammar School. However, despite national and international advertisement, the recruitment process has not seen the emergence of a candidate with the experience and vision required to continue the school’s journey towards excellence.#We are extremely grateful to Miss Stewart, who, as acting head teacher since August , has done an excellent job in leading improvement and taking the school forward.#It adds that, in appointing Mr Mitchell, the council is #pleased to have identied a high-quality solution which ensures the excellence in leadership required in the school#.Mr Mitchell has been head teacher of Dunoon Grammar School for nine years, and has successfully led the school through inspection.He is also an associate assessor with Her Majesty’s Inspectors of Education, and has experience of effectively leading another large secondary school in the authority through a period of transition.#Mr Mitchell’s appointment ensures proven, high-quality leadership in Campbeltown Grammar School,# the letter continues, #and he has a strong record of developing the leadership skills of others in the school.#This relates importantly to the future leadership of Campbeltown Grammar School, as it is not the local authority’s intention to continue the joint head teacher role permanently.#Mr Mitchell will split his week between the two schools, physically basing himself in each school for a dferent part of each week.A senior depute head teacher will be appointed in both schools to undertake the day-to-day running of each school during Mr Mitchell’s time in the other establishment.Regardless of which location he is based in at any particular time, Mr Mitchell will continue to have full head teacher responsibilities for both schools at all times.#I am delighted to have been given the opportunity to lead the team and school community at Campbeltown Grammar School as joint head teacher,# said Mr Mitchell.#I am excited by the excellent work and improvement already happening in the school, and look forward greatly to working with colleagues, pupils, parents carers and partners to fulfil the school’s enormous potential.#I have faith that the whole school community can work together with enthusiasm and creativity to ensure the very best outcomes, opportunities and futures for all our pupils.#The letter adds: #Our aim is to ensure that Campbeltown Grammar School will benefit from the experienced leadership of Mr Mitchell, ensuring that the school community is delivering the best possible educational experiences and outcomes for our children and young people.#

title: from our files march 4 2022
story: Surrounded by family, friends and colleagues, a -year-old retired army major from Campbeltown received a medal years after leaving service.Such a thing is uncommon as normally soldiers receive an honour like this whilst in service.Duncan McMillan, who is well known in the town, joined the army during the Second World War as a private in the Argylls.He was mobilised to France and was at Dunkirk and, after ing to the UK, was later mobilised to North Africa where he was awarded the Military Medal at the Battle of Longstop Hill. He was commissioned in the field in Africa.Later advancing through Italy, Germany and Austria, he ended his service in an Austrian town called Dolsech, after which his home in Campbeltown is named.During discussions on his war service with Lt Col Donald Ross OBE and Col Robert Steele, it became apparent that he had not been awarded the Territorial Decoration to which he was entitled.The army medals office was approached and it was agreed MajMcMillan should receive this honour and he was awarded the Territorial Medal in the Queen’s New Year’s Honours List.At a ceremony last week, his family joined him, including son James who travelled from Canada to witness the medal presentation at the former RAF airbase at Machrihanish.Major McMillan said: #I am delighted to see some of my oldest friends here and as well as receiving this medal, it has made my day.#TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGOIslay’s Ardbeg Distillery has been bought by Glenmorangie plc for £ million.Allied Domecq plc, which owned Ardbeg Distillery, will receive £ million of the total sum in tranches within the next three years.The sale includes the Ardbeg brand, the distillery and surrounding land as well as the stock profile which will come on stream as Ardbeg -year-old and -year-old stocks mature.It will signicantly strengthen Glenmorangie’s current portfolio of malt whiskies which include Glenmorangie and Glen Moray and will provide excellent potential for new brand development, utilising the company’s proven experience in premium brand management.Commenting on the acquisition, Geoffrey Maddrell, chairman of Glenmorangie plc, said: #The company has made signicant progress since the introduction of a new strategy in .#We are particularly confident that our existing portfolio will continue to deliver above average growth and we wish to exploit our marketing capability to achieve a similar success rate with this Islay malt.#An opportunity such as Ardbeg, in a segment of the market which remains under developed, provides us with a rare opportunity.#Glenmorangie is well positioned in the Scotch whisky market, with a strong presence in the malt sector which grew by . per cent in the year to October  in export markets and by  per cent from January to October .FIFTY YEARS AGOMr Lachlan McKinnon, the Mid Argyll, Kintyre and Islay tourist officer, this week reported bumper bookings for the coming season.Talking to a Courier man, Mr McKinnon said that there had been a tremendous boom in the self-catering type of holiday.In fact, the association’s list of cottages, chalets and so on has become exhausted with the result that the months of June, July, August up until the middle of September are fully booked.A total of , enquiries were dealt with in the association’s Campbeltown headquarters by the end of February, an increase of  on last year.Mr McKinnon said he hoped the upward trend in self-catering holidays would continue further and preparations would be made to meet with the demand.It is hoped that the Arran-Kintyre ferry service proposed for this summer will be successful.Mr McKinnon’s plan is to bombard the landing jetty at Claonaig with advertising literature in an attempt to induce motorists south to Campbeltown.He feels strongly that the local authority, hoteliers and businessmen should spend more on advertising nationally in an all-out effort to attract tourism to the burgh.‘Unfortunately the tourist association does not have the money to advertise a specic place. We can only advertise the whole area, which is very large,’ he explained.‘But a town of this size could do a lot more in the way of advertising.’The caravan sites around Campbeltown are among the best in the west of Scotland, Mr McKinnon added.Caravanning, he says, is up and coming in the popularity stakes among holidaymakers.SEVENTY YEARS AGOThe  miners, who had been on an unofficial strike at the Argyll Colliery, Machrihanish, since Monday afternoon of last week, ed to work on Monday morning.This followed meetings of the Argyll branch of the National Union of Mineworkers and the men involved the previous night.It was decided to go back and await the report of the inspector, who, it was stated, was to make an inspection of the colliery on Wednesday.This inspector is appointed by the National Union of Mineworkers and he acts with full approval of the National Coal Board.The strike was in sympathy with two backsht men who walked out because they alleged that part of the pit, where they were working, was unsafe.However, an inspector of the Ministry of Fuel and Power, who made a thorough inspection of the colliery on Thursday, on the recommendation of the manager Mr James W Williamson, reported that the colliery was perfectly safe and that the method of working was highly satisfactory.Prior to his inspection, the men, at one of their meetings in Campbeltown, claimed that too much coal was being extracted from the section concerned and expressed their fear that it might lead to a major disaster.Mr William Marshall, president of the Argyll branch of the NUM and one of the men involved, denied that the two men who originally stopped work because of the alleged danger were men of little mining experience.He stated that one of these men had  years’ experience in mining in the Blantyre district, while the other man had  years’ experience in another Scottish mining area.He argued that on several occasions the men had to quit the road because of creaking and tearing in the roof which were, he said, the usual signs of danger.

title: hoops in whisky barrel sculpture are not in wrong order
story: Campbeltown resident Fiona Macpherson sent a photograph of the installation to the Courier after noticing that the weathered steel rings did not seem to taper out from each end to the middle like the hoops on a whisky cask, which they are supposed to represent.#I looked at the original drawing from the plans and it looks to me like the hoops are in the wrong order,# she said. #It#s nothing like the artist#s impression of how it was going to look.#But Cosmo Blake, network engagement manager at Sustrans Scotland, said the angle of the specic photograph does make it appear as though the outer ring is wider, but #this is not the case in reality#.#To stay true and accurate to traditional whisky and herring barrels, the #taper# on the outer ring of barrels is much lesser by design,# he added.#We are conscious that the previous rendered artist#s impression images of the rings could not illustrate the final and exact angles of the rings in detail.#Named Am Baraille, the feature is part of a joint project between Sustrans and Argyll and Bute Council.It was built near Campbeltown#s New Quay as a visual marker to welcome visitors arriving into Campbeltown by ferry and to mark the start of Sustrans# -mile Caledonia Way cycle route from Campbeltown to Inverness.The six weathered steel rings representing the copper straps of a cask were said to be #informed by community workshops and research of Campbeltown#s whisky and fishing history#.#Art is a fantastic way to spark conversation, create interest and promote unique spaces,# said Mr Blake, #and this artwork, was designed with the local environment and community at its heart.#An interpretation trail, featuring quotes gained from community consultation, leads to and through the sculpture.Ms Macpherson fears these quotes, as they currently are, may be a trip hazard as some of the metal bars on which they are written are sitting slightly proud of the tarmac path.She added: #Also, in the original drawing, the sculpture looks to be set in a sandy surface but it#s actually set in white concrete which is already getting stained, and it#s surrounded by tarmac, neither of which match the surrounding pathways.#It#s an absolute monstrosity, a complete eyesore. With the good news about the new distilleries, we need a better welcome off the ferry than this rusty, bendy barrel.#Mr Blake explained that due to a requirement for drier, warmer weather during installation, as well as the tarmac and concrete requiring  weeks to cure, a final layer of resin-bound material will be laid during spring .#This will bring the level up to the tread plates,# he said.He added that the final ground surface layer was also due for completion in spring.#Once installed, it will result in a colour reflective of the rendered image,# he said.#Sustrans and Argyll and Bute Council officers have worked together closely throughout the entire process.#Argyll and Bute Council owns and maintains the surrounding land and will be taking on ongoing maintenance responsibility for the completed artwork.#The weathered steel materials used are in keeping with the colour of herring and whisky barrel straps, and are incredibly durable which was a key criteria put forward by Argyll and Bute Council, ensuring that the sculpture remains vibrant in the prevailing weather of its coastal location.#The paths, sculpture and materials were all agreed between Sustrans, the artist and Argyll and Bute Council officers prior to designs being submitted for final planning approval, which allowed the wider public the opportunity to comment on these for a further three and a half months through the local authority planning portal.#No objections were received.#An Argyll and Bute Council spokesperson said: #The sculpture is managed and owned by Sustrans and was designed to celebrate the rich heritage of Campbeltown.#We understand the contractor is due toto the site to complete work to the footpath.#

title: leader march 4 2022
story: Ukraine may be fighting one of the biggest and most powerful countries on earth, but it has the strength of the world behind it.The conflict has been described as a #David versus Goliath# war, with Ukraine battling to hold off the armies of its vast neighbour.Despite everything the country is going through, Ukraine#s leaders, military personnel and civilians have proved themselves to be tenacious, resilient, brave – and humorous!Videos showing Ukrainian soldiers dancing to pop music have gone viral on social media, with their ability to live in the moment earning them fans around the globe.Just last year, Ukraine celebrated  years of independence and now its sovereignty is being threatened in the worst way.The preservation of human le should come before all , and any military intervention by NATO countries would undoubtedly increase the death toll exponentially by turning the situation into a global conflict.Will the rest of the continent sit back indefinitely and do nothing but send weapons and impose sanctions while a European country battles for its existence

title: lets get ready to tumble dry shopper aide move sparks expansion
story: Employees of the charity this week washed, dried, ironed and folded the first loads of washing through its new laundry service, after moving its headquarters from a former retail shop on Longrow to a unit at Snipefield Industrial Estate.The new Launder-Aide venture offers a same-day laundry and ironing service, with pick-up and delivery included.‘We had been looking for new premises for some time and the unit has everything we need,’ said Joan Stewart, Shopper-Aide project manager.The building has been altered to suit Shopper-Aide’s needs, with the creation of a reception office space, a group meeting room, a private office and accessible toilets, in addition to the laundry room that was already in the building.There is also a kitchen where Shopper-Aide hopes to make soup which will be sold to the public twice a week.While there are still some small additions to be made to the building, Joan said Andrew Smith, Shopper-Aide’s new landlord, and local tradesmen who have carried out work so far, have been ‘brilliant’ in helping get things up and running.When Shopper-Aide was first set up, to help people aged  and over with their grocery shopping, it was dependent on external funders to operate and pay staff salaries.Over the years, as it began to offer more services including household support, a befriending service and organising social clubs like Elderberries and Garry’s Gang according to clients’ needs and abilities, the charity introduced new initiatives to help generate its own funds.These include selling crafts created by clients at its art and crafts clubs and donated second-hand books and other items.The importance of Shopper-Aide has been highlighted during the Covid pandemic, with its outstanding work in the community earning it a Queen’s Award for Voluntary Service, the UK#s highest award for volunteers.During the first lockdown, the charity’s shopping client-base more than doubled, but an influx of volunteers who were unable to work due to Covid restrictions supported the charity to cope with the increased demand.Volunteers also helped Shopper-Aide to continue providing entertainment to older people throughout lockdown, despite not being able to hold its regular groups, by organising virtual afternoon teas and quizzes and a poetry competition.A ‘Phone Buddies’ system was also set-up, offering one-to-one phone-calls to clients.The charity encouraged its clients to knit squares as part of its ‘lockdown blankets’ project. These were then sewed into blankets which have been donated to three dferent charities to help homeless people.‘During lockdown, it was brought to our attention that it wasn’t only older people with dficulties who struggled,’ Joan said. ‘Everyone felt loneliness.‘To that end, we want to invite everyone, including older people, to come and help us at Shopper-Aide, to help support their community.‘Our volunteers come from all walks of le and are truly tremendous. We wouldn’t be where we are today without them.‘Just an hour a week of someone’s spare time would make an amazing dference to us.’Shopper-Aide is looking for volunteers across all areas of the charity’s work, although it should be noted that people must be aged  or over to drive Shopper-Aide’s vehicles.Garry’s Gang, a men-only group that meets twice a week, was the first to resume when Covid restrictions allowed.One attendee told Shopper-Aide staff: ‘I’m not going to die of Covid, I’m going to die of loneliness.’That is why the charity is keen to restart its social groups as soon as possible, initially in bubbles to ensure safety.‘The last two years, we’ve been on hold, the same the rest of society,’ said Joan, ‘but we’re starting to open our wings and are looking forward to getting back to the new normal.’Shopper-Aide has three full-time and  part-time staff who assist and coordinate volunteers.‘Our staff are very committed,’ Joan said. ‘They all do a brilliant job and go above and beyond what’s asked of them.‘The Shopper-Aide family is committed to supporting each other, and we want to become more resilient should something like Covid ever happen again.’As well as volunteering, people can also support the charity by becoming a ‘Shopper-Aide Friend’ by donating £ a year infor newsletters and the knowledge that they’re supporting a charity within the community.Call   or visit Shopper-Aide’s website or Facebook page for more information on the new laundry service or to support the charity.

title: letters march 4 2022
story: We have recently moved to Carradale, and are loving it!I wrote this poem in praise of our new home.Carradale, O Carradale,Room to stretch, peace to workThe south might say it’s grim up northMay our days be long and all spent hereI urge you alltired and stressedThe story’s just startingTo quote a French poet, Charles Baudelaire,Best wishes.Living in a Campbeltown flat, one up from the street, with only one flat above using the same toilet waste downpipe, I was amazed tohome to find a previous #deposit# still in my toilet.My attempt to clear and flush caused the toilet basin to fill to the brim with #dirty# water etcetera and white paper.The emergency plumbers were called and two good men arrived but efforts to clear the toilet basin in the flat failed.At ground level outside, they effected an entry into the said downpipe and pulled out unpleasant #deposits# and many many wet wipes – which I do not use.They claimed to have previously attended similarly choked toilets with wet wipes. On their advice, I called Scottish Water to report the situation.Their officers attended and completed the clearance into the main drain.It is encouraging to hear that the water companies are taking action to attempt to prevent other householders from sharing my horrible wet wipes experience.Following the recent report from the Public Audit committee, I am calling for a review of governance structures, especially in relation to the Crofting Commission.Crofting in the Highlands and Islands is a huge economic driver that retains people and fights against depopulation.To see that no real improvements have been made to improve the Crofting Commission since concerns were firstly raised is disappointing and concerning and I would like to see this urgently addressed to avoid this occurring again.That is why I believe it would be best to review these governance structures so that the roles within the Crofting Commission – and other bodies – are clear and that its relationship with its board and the Scottish Government are clearly defined.

title: photograph of the week march 4 2022
story: Bob Goodman captured this photograph of massive waves crashing against rocks at Putechan during one spell of wild weather.

title: pupils outdone in last quarter
story: A depleted Campbeltown Pupils senior squad, affected by injury and absence, travelled to Paisley last Saturday to play third-placed St Peter#s, their rd fixture of a hectic but exciting first season in senior football.Previous matches against the Renfrewshire ‘giants’ had been closely fought affairs, and this proved a similar scenario for much of Saturday#s match a gallant effort that saw a determined Kintyre side refuse to be turned at the back as they fought tenaciously to stay in the game against their high-flying opponents.A single goal was the dference between the sides in the first half a huge effort from the visitors that continued deep into the second half before their resolve was broken in the st minute of the match.The Pupils# chance of snatching something from the game disappeared with the loss of the second goal, this before a determined St Peter#s at last found space to score three more before the final whistle.The score was a harsh reflection considering the effort expended but the Pupils will dust themselves down and prepare for the re-match against St Peter#s tomorrowat Kintyre Park.The match, an early chance to recover from their loss of the previous week, has a pm kick-off.Keep an eye on the club’s Twitter and Campbeltown Football Facebook page for up-to-date news of the match and other football notes of interest.

title: pupils u13s well earned draw in game of two halves
story: Campbeltown Pupils sbattled back from three goals down to earn an exciting draw with Busby Amateurs at home on Sunday.It was  a classic game of two halves, with Busby starting the game on the front foot, with a strong wind at their backs, and taking the lead after only five minutes.The visitors soon doubled their lead, with the strong wind assisting a goal directly from a corner, and midway through the half made it three from a loose ball in the penalty box.Finally adjusting to the wind, the locals began fighting their way back into the match.Robert Kerr in the Pupils goal made a series of fine saves to keep the score within touching distance.Just before half-time, the Pupils pulled one back – captain Cohen Campbell drilled a free kick into the box, the ball falling for Ryan Johnston, who calmly finished with a clever lob over the advancing goalkeeper.Coming out for the second half, the Pupils were back in the game, trying to use the wind to their advantage.Midway through the half, the Pupils cut the deficit to one when a whipped corner from Kadyn Prentice found Kerr – now playing outfield – to head home at the back post.The Pupils were well on top, and were finally rewarded with a deserved equaliser with  minutes to play, when Johnston’s in-swinging corner flew past the Busby keeper to make the score -.Neither team could make the decisive breakthrough – Campbell had several fine runs and strikes from distance, and local keeper Alan Myles was called into action as ‘sweeper keeper’ on several occasions, but the score remained level.This Sunday, the Pupils under-s travel to play BSC Glasgows.

title: thought for the week march 4 2022
story: Teachers of wisdom spring up like weeds after rain. They are innovative in the way they deal with reality, breaking existing norms, bending the truth, and promising quick and easy success.However, when a disciple of Christ sees the impermanence of earthly riches, he will see the invitation to persist in prayer, so as to maintain the true purpose and meaning of le.Saint James, in his letter, encourages perseverance in prayer during peace and health as well as in misfortune and suffering.It’s also about faith and the courage to be able to stand before the Lord.And this is not lacking in those who pray for peace and justice in Ukraine.People on their knees in the streets pleading in prayer for help. A young father crying as he sends his family away to safety, children hidden in shelters – and the world perseveres in prayer, in which every heart and knee is bent in prayer, and hands moving along the beads are a chain linking heaven to earth.And arms have been opened to embrace hundreds of thousands of refugees, women, children and the elderly.Bravery and courage came to the fore, and a people united to protect, help and support each other. Many nations came together to rebuke the aggressor and sustain the victim.A nation that is indignant has a right to hope, but woe to the one who rots in silence. I will persevere in prayer and offer what I can to aid the innocent.Do you believe in the power of prayer  Do you believe that what is asked for in faith will be received  Do you believe that evil will ultimately be defeated by good  Do you have hope

title: withdrawal from fisheries negotiations involving russian federation
story: In a letter to the UK Government, Ms Gougeon said talks should be postponed and said the Scottish Government will not engage in any fisheries negotiations involving the Russian Federation.#To allow the Russian Federation to participate, remotely or in person, in such discussions would be an insult to our Ukrainian friends and partners,# said Ms Gougeon.#It would allow the Russian Federation to assume a veneer of legitimacy at a time when their flagrant breaches of international law have placed them beyond the pale of the rules-based global order.#

title: gardening in march it starts with a seed
story: This is the month for sowing seeds and getting the garden ready for the summer months ahead.But, before you rush to get sowing, just take some to time to plan what you want to grow, how many plants you are going to need and when you want them to flower or bear fruit. This is particularly good advice for anyone with a vegetable plot.A sowing plan of what seeds and how many to sow each month is your key to successful growing and means that you won#t be throwing out unwanted seedlings and that your flower and vegetable beds will be full all year round.A word of warning about sowing directly into the ground at this time of year, there may be a few sunny days to enjoy outside but the soil can still be chilly, making germination and survival hard.Sowing indoors is a better option not only does it provide a warm environment for germination but seeds and seedlings are easier to protect from pests.If you can find some environmentally sound sowing trays and containers, rather than using plastic, then even better. Paper and cardboard pots can be packed snugly in a tray which avoids over handling and makes them easy to water.Small seeds should be scattered sparingly on the surface of compost-filled seed trays and then covered with a sprinkling of sieved compost.If the seeds are big enough to handle, then you can sow them inidually into cm pots – the quantity should be according to the instructions specied on the seed packet, but usually for small seeds, between five- seeds per pot.For plants that grow long roots, such as peas or beans, you can put them into a compost-filled cardboard toilet roll tube and, once ready, they can then be planted outside tube and all.Most seeds will germinate and grow in a warm setting such as a greenhouse, cold frame or on a sunny windowsill.You should keep them damp by using a mist spray to start with before moving onto a watering can with a fine rose nozzle.Once the seedlings have grown their second pair of leaves and before they get too squashed in seed trays or pots, pot them on into small pots.Simply ease out a clump of seedlings with an old cutlery fork or dibber and – handling only the leaves to avoid damaging delicate stems and roots – gently tease them apart.Drop inidual seedlings into a cm compost-filled newspaper pot ensuring the lower leaves are above the compost level.Once you see roots appearing from the bottom of the pot, it’s time to pot on to a bigger pot before planting outside once the weather and soil warms up.If you are growing your own vegetables, now is a good time to sow first early potatoes.These can be planted from mid-March however planting times will y across the country, according to temperature and risk of frost.Early potatoes grow well in the ground and in containers such as potato grow bags or old compost bags.You should plant your chitted potatoes with the shoots facing upwards in soil with plenty of well-rotted organic matter, and approximately cm deep and cm apart.Once stems are about cm tall, they will need earthing up – by drawing soil around them to create a cm high ridge, to protect against frost and keep growing potatoes covered.Good ieties of early potatoes are: Swt – good for containers, white skinned and white fleshed Annabelle – nutty flavour with firm waxy yellow flesh Maris Bard – white flesh with good ‘new potato’ flavour and drought resistance.Spring seems tantalisingly close in March, particularly as work in the garden starts to get going again.According to the Royal Horticultural Society, spring usually arrives by mid-March and the frequent sunny days provide the opportunity for an increasing range of gardening tasks.It#s time to get busy preparing seed beds, sowing seed, cutting back winter shrubs and generally tidying up around the garden.

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as “a real dream come true”.She said: “We are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.”Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk – The Cheese Lady – has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: “We needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.“We want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.“Also, I’m hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.”Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: “Whoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  That’s fantastic.“And it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.”Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: “I think we are in a good place.“When we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!”

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than £,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: “We are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.“Mary has raised a fantastic £, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.”Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised £, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Roman’s Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: “This year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.“I’m walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!”People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: save-50-per-cent-full-year-access-east-lothian-courier
story: There is never a shortfall of news in our fantastic area and it is our passion to keep you informed.However, for our team to be able to provide outstanding local coverage we ask for your support in the form of a digital subscription. We are now offering a limited time offer which will save you % on our annual plan. title: knox-academy-headteacher-urges-pupils-dress-appropriately-decline-standard-uniform
story: Letters have been sent to parents and carers encouraging them to ensure pupils are wearing the appropriate unorm when heading to school.The letter, sent out last Thursday, noted that Covid- mitigations were reducing and attempts were being made to “ to a more ‘normal’ approach to le”.Sue Cook, headteacher at the school, stressed the importance of wearing the school unorm.She said: “Over the past few months, we have noticed a decline in the standard of unorm worn by some of our pupils.“This has included non-black trousers, ripped trousers, crew neck jumpers, leggings sports leggings, jogging bottoms, hooded topsand tops which are short cropped.“None of these items are part of our school unorm and they are not appropriate attire for school.“I would like to stress that the vast majority of young people are dressed appropriately, but the number of young people who are not following unorm expectations has increased.“In the coming weeks and months, we plan to increase our approaches to unorm checks and upholding the expectation of young people wearing a unorm.“We need to know, at a glance, that the young people in the school building are pupils at this school and the school unorm is always a quick way of ensuring this.“A school unorm is something that should be al and not necessarily fashionable.“It also supports our approaches to equity.”

title: overnight-resurfacing-works-a1-thistly-cross-roundabout
story: Transport Scotland’s operating company BEAR Scotland were due to start the works on Tuesday but the work was delayed due to adverse weather conditions.A total of  metres of the westbound section of road on the approach to the Thistly Cross Roundabout is being resurfaced.A spokesperson for BEAR Scotland confirmed the works would take place from .pm to am each day, excluding Saturday and Sunday, until next Friday .He told the Courier: “The reason for the extra nights is that we now only have one team available for this job rather than two.”A signed ersion route will be in place via the A, Countess Road and Summerfield Road through Dunbar, before re-joining the A to Beltonford Roundabout and taking the A to Haddington Junction on the A.The road is closed to ensure the safety of roadworkers and the public during these times.Emergency services will be given access through the works at all times and local access for residents within the closure points will be maintained when it is safe to pass through the work area.

title: new-torness-boss-hopes-find-job-everyone
story: It was confirmed at the end of last year that the nuclear power station would now close two years earlier than planned.About  staff and more than a hundred contractors are employed at the station, which was due to close in March .That timescale has been brought forward two years and Paul Forrest, new station director, stressed that the immediate focus was on continuing generation but that attention would turn to the future of the station within the next couple of years.He said: “These are big institutions and preparation work needs to start, maybe not now but over the next year or so.“We found our first keyway root crack at our inspections there and it was expected.“We found a keyway root cracking at Hunterston in  and some keyway root cracking at Heysham , our sister station, last year. That is within expectations but what that does do is underpins the  date so I think we are more confident now that that will be the date.“One success we got from the Hunterston end-of-generation is we managed to find a job for everybody who wanted to stay here.“The staff levels do go down, there’s no doubt about it, but I’ve just done it.“Hunterston was the first station of the AGR [advanced gas-cooled reactor] fleet to reach the end of generation. I was there, I saw it all, so I’m well positioned to help Torness on their journey. We will be starting our preparations for that in the next couple of years.”Once the station stops generating power, attention will turn to defueling the reactors.That process is expected to take more than three years and will require hundreds of members of staff.Mr Forrest succeeded Tam Al Bishawi, who has moved to EDF’s new Hinkley C power station in Somerset after  years over two spells at the station.However, the -year-old is no stranger to Torness.He has lived in nearby Dunbar for more than  years and has a connection with the power station dating back more than  years.He was involved in the construction and commissioning of the station and has held ious roles, including operations manager and technical and safety manager.He was also plant manager at Torness for nearly two years from December  to September , when he was appointed acting station director at Hunterston B, near West Kilbride in Ayrshire.The “strong supporter” of nuclear power felt that Torness had an important role to play in the years ahead.The father-of-three said: “I will be painting that picture and, as I said, at Hunterston we managed to find a job for everybody who wanted to stay. If I can replicate that, it would be a real success.“That will be one of my main focuses but right now we are generating electricity for about a quarter of Scotland’s electricity needs and that is low-carbon electricity.”

title: controlled-explosion-item-address-west-barns
story: An official police statement to the Courier yesterday said that bomb disposal experts had carried out the controlled explosion on Tuesday - but that information was wrong.Apologising for any inconvience caused, a Police Scotland statement this morning said: "Information initially provided relating to a controlled explosion at the address was inaccurate. No controlled explosion occurred.": Man arrested in West BarnsTodays statement added: "Enquiries are continuing at an address in West Barns. A -year-old man was arrested and released pending further enquiries."For the past week there has been a signicant police, fire and ambulance service presence in West Barns.Police have declined to disclose the nature of the incident but reassured members of the public yesterday that there was no reason to be alarmed nor risk to them and that a police presence would remain in the area as enquiries continued.

title: tower-tranent-pub-back-bang
story: The Tower, formerly The Tower Inn, on Church Street, held a grand opening on Saturday to toast to the doors of the iconic watering hole opening once more.It followed a brief closure of the pub, established in , when it was seemingly sold for residential purposes at the beginning of the year.The building has since been bought back and leased out to remain a community pub to be ran by new business managers Dominic McNeill and Patrick Cairney.The cousins thanked everyone that came out on Saturday and said it had been “a great success”.They added: “We have made the decision to open the pub full time to allow more access to the community.”The new opening hours are: Monday-Wednesday: am-pm Thursday: am-midnight Friday-Saturday: am-am Sunday: am-midnight.A number of events will be announced in the coming weeks, with visitors encouraged to suggest things they would like to see at the pub.Dominic and Patrick added: “Thank you all and please keep the ideas coming, we are listening and are in the middle of implementing some of these ideas.”

title: alpacas-pay-visit-leuchie-house-near-north-berwick
story: Ouzo, Sabre and Mr Darcy made the trip from John Muir Alpacas at Hedderwickhill Farm, near Dunbar, which is home to a herd of  animals.The animals provided entertainment in exchange for carrots.Leuchie House provides care and holiday breaks for people with neurological conditions and the team welcomed the alpacas’ visit for providing their guests with a memorable experience.Victoria Shields, guest engagement manager, said: “The guests really enjoyed the experience and getting to see the alpacas up close. “We are extremely grateful to the team at John Muir Alpacas for bringing them to see us, and we would love to welcome them back again.”

title: dunbar-pipe-band-championships-postponed-third-year
story: Bands from throughout Scotland regularly head to the town for the annual Dunbar Pipe Band Championships.The event, which is held at Hallhill Sports Centre, has been cancelled the last two years due to the coronavirus pandemic.It now looks like this year’s event, scheduled for May , will also not go ahead.Bobby Peters, manager of the sports centre, was disappointed but confident it wouldin .He said: “East Lothian Council, like every other council, has cut back on funding.“Obviously, we lost  and  due to Covid and we knew about the funding and we thought we had somebody  lined up.“Unfortunately, that has not materialised and it looks like we are going to lose it this year.”The event, which features Highland dancing and music by pipe bands from across the country, often attracts more than , people.However, Mr Peters told the Courier that funding of between £, and £, was necessary to hold the event.He said: “It could be this year we have to give it a miss but next year we work harder. In January, we did not even know where we were going to be and were still in the middle of a pandemic nobody knew what was coming.“If it does not happen this year, it will happen next year.”Already, a fundraising page has been set up to try to raise the funding for next year.To make a donation, go to www.gofundme f dunbar-pipe-band-day-

title: plans-gullane-holiday-let-approved
story: Retrospective planning permission was needed for the change of use on Gullane’s Hopetoun Terrace.No changes are to be made to the inside or outside of the flat under Christine Povey’s plans.East Lothian Council noted that no members of the public had objected, while the village’s community council also had no views.The planning department also looked at the duration of the stays.More than halfwere said to be people staying for two or three nights, with the majority being couples aged between  and .Forty-five per cent were said to be for one night, while just five per cent of those using the building were there for between seven and  nights.It was noted the longer stays were often people visiting family members.

title: edinburgh-duathlon-fitness-event-cause-disruption-drivers
story: The Edinburgh Duathlon, which sets off from Gosford House on Sunday at am, is the second duathlon to be held at the county house.The duathlon includes a k run, followed by a k cycle and concluded with another k run.The event, organised by Tough Runner UK, will take place within Gosford House estate and follow a bike course along the coastline.The bicycle route. Image: https:www.plotaroute Due to the event, a lower speed limit of mph on the A between Longniddry and Aberlady from am until pm on Sunday.The section of the A is from  metres north of junction with Wemyss Terrace in Longniddry to the junction with The Pleasance in Aberlady for a distance of .km.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-march-3-7-1997-1972-1922
story: ‘COUNCIL tax rise among lowest in Scotland’ was front page news in the East Lothian Courier on March , .An eight per cent rise in council tax will add £ – just over £ a week – to the annual bill of Band D households in East Lothian, coupled with £. million cuts affecting every area of council spending.Agreeing one of the lowest increases of any Scottish authority yesterday , councillors pledged to protect front-line services such as teachers and home helps and said no public facilities would close.The annual Band D tax bill of £ is coupled with an eight per cent rise in the domestic rate announced by East of Scotland Water which will add an average p per week, giving a combined weekly rate of £. compared with £. last year.East Lothian Council leader, Norman Murray, said: “This has proved the most dficult budget exercise we as councillors have ever had to go through.”  ‘Keeping down vermin’ was a headline in the East Lothian Courier on March , .If council house tenants in Tranent find rats in their homes, Rentokil Laboratories Ltd., will be contacted immediately.This assurance was given by the Clerk of Works, Mr George Gray, at Monday’s meeting of the Town Council.The Council agreed to use the services of Rentokil to get rid of rats and mice.The firm had inspected hedgerows and open spaces in the burgh and found rats and mice in the areas of Seton Court, Fleets Road, Elphinstone Crescent, Blawearie Road, Coalgate Avenue and Sandersons Wynd.In a letter to the Council, Rentokil outlined their pest control plans.They proposed eight inspections and treatments per annum in hedgerows and open ground areas, excluding privately owned and industrial areas. They would carry out treatment against rats and mice in Town Council dwelling houses as the need arose.  AN ALARMING fire ripped through a premises in Dunbar, as reported in The Haddingtonshire Courier on March , .An outbreak of fire, the origin of which is unknown, occurred during the early hours of Friday morning, within the stationary premises owned by Miss Downie.The smell of burning attracted the attention of a lady who resides above the shop, and who promptly gave the alarm.The fire brigade, under Mr Murdoch, was quickly on the spot and had it not been for the expeditious manner in which they tackled the outbreak, the whole tenement might have been destroyed.

title: easter-egg-trail-returns-newhailes-house-gardens
story: The fun trails, forced to be put on hold due to Covid- after Easter , were a fixture of many families’ spring holidays, with about , visitors taking part each year.Newhailes joins  other National Trust for Scotlandproperties to take part in the event from Friday, April , to Monday, April .Visitors can enjoy exploring the grounds of some of Scotland’s most beautul sites, following clues, solving a puzzle and collecting a chocolate reward.Newhailes will also welcome the circus and there will be  hidden golden bunnies around the property, with an additional prize up for grabs for those who find one.Mark Bishop, director of customer and cause for NTS, said: “All of us here at the National Trust for Scotland are so excited to confirm theof our Easter Egg Trails for April.“For our charity, these events are a highlight of our year.”For the full programme of events, see nts.org.uk easter

title: red-letter-days-reveals-adventure-experiences-like-batman---book
story: To celebrate the highly anticipated release of The Batman, the experience days website has brought together some of its exciting adventure experiences to really put hairs on the back of your neck.Save the world and take the wheel of the Batmobile or savour a DC comics-inspired three-course meal.The Batman has no limits and neither should you, here are some of the best experience days to try from Red Letter Days.Superhero Six Mile Driving Thrill. Credit: Red Letter Days Take the drivers seat of the Batmobile because Gotham isnt going to save itself.This unique driving experience is ideal for superhero fans with a need for speed.The Bat-themed car became an iconic symbol for the superhero ever since the original TV series and now fans can put it to the test on a six-mile track.You will receive a full introduction and safety briefing before taking the wheel of the replica car and it is available at  places across the country. The unforgettable experience will cost you £ per person, which is down from £.Put the Batmobile to the test today by visiting the Red Letter Days website.Three Course DC Inspired Lunch at Park Row for Two. Credit: Red Letter Days Enjoy an immersive dining experience at Park Row that will bring the DC Universe to le.Inside a stunning Art Deco building in the heart of Londons Theatreland,  youll find five themed restaurants and bars dedicated to the wonders of DC Comics.Red Letter Days has said that you should "prepare for the unexpected" with this scrummy superhero treat which features everything from levitating drinks to nitro popcorn.Sample three delicious courses from its set menu before taking a tour of the ious themed spaces that Park Row has to offer and enjoying a levitating alcoholic drop each.The exclusive DC-inspired experience is £ for two people and can be purchased now from the Red Letter Days website.                                                                                                              : The Batman review: Glasgow gets its share of the spotlight in Robert Pattinsons Batman debut: Red Letter Days reveals Mothers Day guide with Hot Air Balloon rides and Afternoon Tea                                                                                                                 Three Mile Superhero Driving Thrill. Credit: Red Letter Days Do you want to play Batman but dont want to break the bank  Now you can, with this -mile thrilling drive experience in a replica of the iconic Batmobile.Youll get a full introduction and safety briefing before you fire up the exhaust and play Gothams iconic vigilante.This heart-racing experience is ideal for any Batman fans and can be used at  locations across the UK.It is also been reduced from £ to just £ which makes an absolute bargain. Purchase the Batmobile experience via the Red Letter Days website.Superhero CAPOW Photoshoot Click Connection. title: tried-marine-hotel---went
story: It is impossible to stay at The Marine North Berwick and not immediately start picturing yourself in F. Scott Fitzgerald’s classic novel The Great Gatsby.More than one person staying informed us that the hotel hadn’t always been that way but, after a dramatic refurbishment last year, the move from bleak to chic has been swt and drastic.The Marine now offers  guest rooms, two unique food and beverage concepts, a spa, pool and fitness centre, and , square feet of flexible meeting and event spaces.Overlooking the th hole of the historic West Links course of North Berwick Golf Club, it boasts scenic views of landmarks including the Firth of Forth and Bass Rock.The panoramic and clear views of sea from the hotel are even betteryou’re lucky enough to catch the East Lothian weather on a good day.But though rainy and bleak during our stay, the views were equally breathtaking. With the lobby offering seating – and a coffee and cocktail service! – and a large welcome desk in the centre of the room, even the reception does its best to cater to the view. It would be easy to spend an entire afternoon in the lobby alone, getting lost in the town’s beauty.Its fair to say, the ‘Grand Old Lady’ is back to her former glory and better than ever...Marine Hotel, North Berwick Set on Cromwell Road, The Marine Hotel North Berwick occupies a prime position just streets away from the town’s charming beach and harbour. Its buttercream stone facade is easy to locate and its large free parking area means carrying luggage to the door is a breeze.For tourists and visitors, the hotel is in a prime position within walking distance of a iety of restaurants, some of which serve the freshest seafood from the harbour, alongside fish and chip takeaways and the well-loved and always popular Alandas Gelato.Upon entry to the hotel foyer, guests will be blown away by the sublime views out of large open windows of the iconic Bass Rock.The revamped Marine Hotel, North Berwick There’s ample free parking, a large restaurant, bar area, spa facilities, free Wi-Fi and more.The lobby at night The design throughout the hotel takes inspiration from Scotland’s world-renowned golf courses and notable figures, with nods to the hotel’s stunning seaside location and surrounding natural wonders.A deep colour palette dominates here: the lobby is a mixed wash of patterned wallpaper and dark emerald window fittings. Seating areas boast a selection of large leather couches and intimate tables of two – both of which offer stunning views of the waters that make North Berwick so popular.The hotel embraces the beauty of the wilderness on its front door, with interiors pulling from the agricultural and architectural history of the area. Local heritage is displayed through framed prints of wildle found on the Bass Rock. The refurbished style is reminiscent of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s classic The Great Gatsby.The lobby area boasts walls of literature As a perfect location for tourists and local visitors alike, there was a iety of visitors checking in: in the lobby, a mix of young couples and groups of friends, as well as solo visitors with their beloved pooches, socialised.The service was relaxed and without fault. Reception staff were friendly and engaging, recommending restaurants and sight-seeing activities.During checkout, staff members went above and beyond to cater to guests’ needs, with several carrying luggage out to the car park and ensuring checkout was as speedy and calm as possible.Bedside tables reflect the hotels golfing roots The hotel boasts  guest rooms, with many paying homages to iconic golf holes with nightstands designed as golf tee boxes. Guest room carpet complements the nightstands and depicts golf ball and golf club mots within the traditional pattern.Each room is somewhat unique but adheres to the core theme by using pops of deep colour and golfing mots to reflect its sporting heritage.All rooms – Marine King Suite, Marine Deluxe King Seaview, Marine Deluxe King, Marine Classic Double Seaview, Marine Classic Double – come with sizeable bathrooms, high-end toiletries, storage space, iron, safe, coffee and tea, concierge service and a mini-bar.My only criticism is the not-so-subtle patterned wallpaper featured in a number of bedrooms. I would avoid thoseyou are prone to migraines!Haggis Bonbons made a great starter The Marine’s restaurant, The Lawn, offers erse dining options and an extensive all-day menu showcasing the very best of Scottish cuisine. Main courses include options of venison, halibut and duck breast.The quality of the food is a definite selling point I’d recommend the haggis bonbons to start, while the Tweed valley beef with Chimichurri sauce makes for an admirable main course.The only distraction in the dining area was the rather bleak music played throughout dinner. Additionally, I would recommend a late dinner, with the atmosphere of the eatery heating up at around pm.Breakfast is a generous premium buffet served in the restaurant with an additional menu of warm and cooked items the French toast is not to be missed. From my understanding, the pastries on offer at the buffet are made in house and the best I’ve ever eaten.The overall dining experience at The Lawn was high class, most of all due to the eagerness and humour of our server. If you visit The Lawn, with or without a booked stay at The Marine, always ask for Richie!Cocktails created by talented bar staff are the perfect dinner treat Staff are faultless in their presentation, their unorm neat and matching they’re eager to help and accommodate.Marine Hotel North Berwick Without a doubt, the staff are among the most polite and caring I have ever met. A special mention goes to Surajit Dasgupta for his outstanding care and attention throughout the stay. His service alone would justy booking a night’s stay at The Marine.The atmosphere and charm of this hotel is so special that, despite living just a few miles down the road, it felt like a well-needed break from day-to-day le. This does not give you the routine chain hotel vibe, instead a comfortable stay high up on my list of places to . Huge respect to the Marine team, who do a great job here a true example of excellent hospitality!

title: quiet-roads-coming-county
story: East Lothian Council’s Labour-led cabinet is being asked to decide whether to keep the the limits and introduce a new hierarchy of speed restrictions on its roads orto pre-pandemic rules.A new speed limit policy also proposes introducing Quiet Roads in the county which would have signs urging drivers to go slower on lanes which are being used by pedestrians and cyclists.The new policy follows a survey of residents last year which the council says saw six out of  people say they believed the lower speed limits have made it safer for children, with more than half keen to keep them in some,not all, places.However it also found  per cent of residents said drivers ignored the speed limits and more than half said drivers took more risks and were frustrated by the slower speeds, with  per cent having the view that speed limits were not enforced.However  per cent of people questioned said they believed drivers paid more attention to other road users due to reduced speed limits and were less likely to overtake cyclists with a third adding they found it easier to cross roads.: Public urged to have their say on mph zonesThe proposed hierarchy of speeds in East Lothian’s towns would see mph limits on roads on the outskirts of communities, with mph roads described as streets where vehicles are given a higher priority than the “place ”.Speed limits of mph would be introduced in residential streets or those with a high pedestrian or cyclist movement such as town centres or around schools.The policy also covers ways for communities to apply for changes to speed limits in their areas.And it introduces the designation of popular walking areas as Quiet Roads.It says: “Quiet Roads are increasingly being implemented on rural roads across Scotland where there may be high levels of use by pedestrians, cyclists or equestrians.“The presence of vulnerable road users in the carriageway is highlighted to drivers through the use of signage to promote a shared environment.“Where appropriate, East Lothian Council will consider the introduction of Quiet Roads across its network to develop safer movements for vulnerable road users.”

title: mothers-day-gifts-2022-coffee-machines-mugs-gift-sets

Via Canva Pixabay.
